title: RNA Splice: Isoform Switching Analysis
description: Isoform switch detection with functional consequence prediction. Identifies transcript isoforms with opposite regulation and predicts protein domain changes, NMD sensitivity, and clinical implications. Samplesheet format: `sample,fastq_1,fastq_2,strandedness,condition`
content:
RNA Splice: Isoform Switching

Isoform switching occurs when the dominant transcript isoform changes between conditions - a key regulatory mechanism where gene-level expression may be unchanged but protein function dramatically differs.

What is an Isoform Switch?

When comparing two conditions, an isoform switch means:

  • One isoform significantly increases (e.g., isoform A goes from 30% → 70%)
  • Another decreases (e.g., isoform B goes from 70% → 30%)
  • Total gene expression may be similar
  • But protein function/localization/stability changes dramatically

Why Isoform Switches Matter

  • Protein Function: Gain/loss of protein domains
  • Localization: Nuclear vs cytoplasmic targeting
  • Stability: NMD-sensitive vs stable isoforms
  • Drug Targets: Kinase domain inclusion/exclusion
  • Disease Mechanisms: Pro-apoptotic ↔ anti-apoptotic switches

Functional Consequences Analyzed

Protein Coding Potential:

  • Coding vs non-coding isoform switches
  • Premature stop codons
  • Truncated proteins

Protein Domains (Pfam):

  • Gain/loss of functional domains
  • Kinase domains, DNA-binding domains
  • Transmembrane regions, signal peptides

Signal Peptides:

  • Secreted vs intracellular
  • Membrane targeting

NMD Sensitivity:

  • Nonsense-mediated decay targeting
  • Isoforms with PTCs >50nt upstream of last exon junction

Intrinsically Disordered Regions (IDRs):

  • Protein-protein interaction sites
  • Regulatory regions

Example Isoform Switches

BCL-X (BCL2L1):

  • BCL-XL (long): Anti-apoptotic, blocks cell death
  • BCL-XS (short): Pro-apoptotic, promotes cell death
  • Cancer: Shift to BCL-XL promotes survival
  • Therapy: Splice-switching oligonucleotides (SSO) shift to BCL-XS

CD44:

  • Standard form (CD44s): Cell adhesion
  • Variant forms (CD44v): Include variable exons, promote metastasis
  • Cancer: Switch to CD44v isoforms in EMT, invasion

VEGF-A:

  • VEGF165: Pro-angiogenic (standard)
  • VEGF165b: Anti-angiogenic (distal splice site in exon 8)
  • Cancer: Balance shifted to pro-angiogenic

Ron (MST1R):

  • Full-length Ron: Normal receptor signaling
  • ΔRON (Δexon11): Constitutively active, oncogenic
  • Cancer: Switch to ΔRON in breast, colon cancer

Pipeline Analysis Steps

  1. Transcript Quantification: Salmon TPM for all isoforms
  2. Switch Detection: IsoformSwitchAnalyzeR identifies opposite regulation
  3. ORF Prediction: Identify coding sequences (CPAT, ORFfinder)
  4. Domain Annotation: Pfam domain search
  5. Signal Peptide: SignalP prediction
  6. NMD Prediction: Identify PTC-containing isoforms
  7. Functional Impact: Score consequence severity

Switch Detection Criteria

Typical thresholds:

  • dIF (delta Isoform Fraction) > 0.1: 10% shift in usage
  • FDR < 0.05: Statistical significance
  • Opposite regulation: One isoform up, another down
  • Functional consequence: Domain/NMD/signal peptide changes

Clinical Applications

Cancer Biomarkers:

  • BCL-X isoform ratio predicts chemotherapy response
  • CD44 variants mark cancer stem cells
  • FGFR2-IIIc expression predicts metastasis

Therapeutic Targets:

  • Splice-switching oligonucleotides (SSOs)
  • Small molecule splicing modulators
  • Spinraza (nusinersen): SSO for SMA (SMN2 exon 7 inclusion)
  • Risdiplam: Small molecule for SMN2

Drug Response:

  • Kinase isoforms with/without inhibitor-binding domains
  • Receptor isoforms affecting antibody binding

Key Outputs

  • Switch Analysis: Genes with significant isoform switches
  • Consequence Predictions: Domain, NMD, signal peptide changes
  • Switch Plots: Isoform fraction changes visualized
  • Functional Annotations: Pfam, SignalP, CPAT results
  • Top Candidates: Prioritized switches with functional impact

Perfect for: Cancer isoform biomarkers • Therapeutic target discovery • Functional isoform annotation • Splice therapy development • Disease mechanisms
